title: Domain 1.6: Compare and contrast network topologies, architectures, and types.
content:
ğŸ”— Mesh

A network topology where each device is connected to every other device, offering high redundancy and reliability. This topology is often used in critical, high-availability systems.

Pro: Highly resilient to failures.

Con: Expensive and complex to set up and maintain.

ğŸ”„ Hybrid

A combination of two or more network topologies, designed to combine the benefits of different setups based on specific needs.

Example: A hybrid network might combine a star topology in one area and a mesh in another, depending on the criticality of connections.

â­ Star/Hub and Spoke

A topology where all devices are connected to a central hub or switch.

Pro: Centralized management and easy to scale.

Con: The central hub is a single point of failure.

ğŸƒ Spine and Leaf

A modern data center network architecture where spine switches are connected to leaf switches. Leaf switches connect to devices, while spine switches connect leaf switches together.

Pro: Efficient routing, low latency, and high scalability in data centers.

Con: Can be complex to design for large networks.

â†”ï¸ Point to Point

A simple topology where two devices are directly connected to each other with a dedicated link.

Pro: Reliable and easy to manage.

Con: Limited scalability, as each new connection requires a dedicated link.

ğŸ›ï¸ Three-Tier Hierarchical Model

Core: The backbone layer where high-speed switching happens, connecting various distribution and access layers.

Distribution: Responsible for routing and policy-based control of traffic.

Access: Where end devices like computers and printers are connected.

ğŸŒ Traffic Flows

â¬‡ï¸ North-South

Refers to data flow between end-user devices (like computers) and the data center or cloud. This is the traditional "client-server" communication model.

â†”ï¸ East-West

Refers to data flow within the data center or between servers. This is often higher-volume traffic within a network, such as between application servers or database clusters.

ğŸ¢ Collapsed Core

A simplified version of the three-tier model, where the core and distribution layers are merged into a single layer. This is commonly used in smaller networks or environments where simplicity is prioritized.

Pro: Simplified network architecture and easier management.

Con: Less scalability compared to a full three-tier model.
